presenting_history: The patient has been experiencing intermittent abdominal pain for 3 months. The pain occurs daily but comes and goes, is central in location with no radiation, and has a squeezing colicky character. Pain score is 6-7/10. He took paracetamol but it did not help. The pain is better with defecation. He is still passing flatus. Associated with constipation for more than 6 months - previously passed motion once a day with soft stools, now only once in 3-4 days with hard lumpy stools. Last bowel opening was yesterday, normal amount but hard stools. No per rectal bleeding, no change in stool caliber, no tenesmus, no nausea or vomiting. Also has loss of appetite for more than 6 months with 3kg weight loss over the past year. Used to take 3 full meals but now feels less hungry and can barely finish half portions. Still tries to eat vegetables and fruits 1-2 portions a day. Drinks at least 1.5L water daily. No early satiety, dysphagia or odynophagia.
past_medical_history: Stage IV Metastatic Colorectal Cancer (sigmoid colon with lung metastases) - diagnosed April 2024, declined palliative chemotherapy
Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus - diagnosed 8 years ago, on metformin 250mg BD, HbA1c 6.4%
Osteoarthritis of left knee - on glucosamine and calcium/vitamin D
medications: Lactulose 10ml BD PRN (not keen to take)
social_history: Retired engineer. No financial difficulties. Married with 2 children who stay separately. Living with elderly wife in 4-room HDB flat with lift landing, EASE modifications completed. Cordial relationship with wife who is sad but coping with his diagnosis. Non-smoker. No alcohol. Goes for daily walks in the morning with wife and still enjoys doing so.
oncology_history: Underwent colonoscopy in April 2024 for change in bowel habits. Found to have sigmoid colon cancer with biopsy-confirmed malignancy. Staging CT showed multiple lung metastases in both lungs (not amenable to metastasectomy). No liver, bone, or brain metastases. Discussed with surgeons and medical oncologist - not suitable for curative surgery. Stenting offered but patient declined due to discomfort during colonoscopy. Offered palliative chemotherapy at last medical oncology follow-up 3 months ago but patient declined as it is not curative and worried about side effects. Stopped follow-ups after that as felt nothing else could be done. Told prognosis without treatment is 6 months to a year.
script_instructions: You are playing Mr. Andy Lee, a 72-year-old Chinese Singaporean man with terminal colorectal cancer. Your demeanor is calm and resigned but troubled. Initially you are reluctant to discuss your cancer as you feel 'no hope already' and stopped going for follow-ups. You declined chemotherapy because doctors said it was not curative and you worried about side effects. You are getting to terms with your diagnosis after initial shock and sadness. Your family has been supportive. You have some worries about pain and end-of-life planning. You take a little longer to fall asleep due to thinking but can maintain sleep. You are NOT depressed (PHQ-2: 0). You have no concrete thoughts about end-of-life planning like preferred place of death, funeral arrangements, or financial arrangements like living will. You just wish to be comfortable in your last days. If asked about lactulose, express concern it may worsen your diabetes. If offered referral to palliative care, initially hesitate saying you thought nothing else could be done, but agree after explanation of how palliative care can help with symptom control and end-of-life planning. Speak in clear, natural English.
secret_info: The patient was previously given lactulose but is not keen to take it as he is worried it may worsen his diabetes. He stopped going for oncology follow-ups because he felt hopeless after learning chemotherapy was not curative. His wife is aware of the diagnosis but the family has not discussed what to do if his condition deteriorates. He would be interested in palliative care referral if explained properly that it is about comfort and quality of life, not giving up. He is not keen on hospital admission and values time with family given his limited prognosis.
expected_diagnosis: Constipation colic secondary to metastatic colorectal cancer; Palliative care needs assessment
